guideline.name: Annotation of DPWG Guideline for lamotrigine and HLA-B

relatedGenes.name: major histocompatibility complex, class I, B

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166299278

text.html:
• Carefully weigh the risk of SJS/TEN against the benefits.
  • Avoid lamotrigine if an alternative is available.
    • Carbamazepine carries a much higher risk of SJS/TEN in these patients and is therefore not an alternative.
    • A similar risk has been reported for phenytoin as for lamotrigine.
    • The same applies to oxcarbazepine, but the most severe forms (SJS/TEN overlap and TEN) have not been observed with oxcarbazepine.
  • If it is not possible to avoid these products, advise the patient to report any rash immediately.

implications: The life-threatening cutaneous side effect Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (SJS/TEN) occurs more often in patients with this genetic variation. Based on the estimated risk for all patients and the increase by a factor 3.6 for patients with this genetic variation, the risk of lamotrigine-induced SJS/TEN in patients with HLA-B*1502 is estimated at 0.4%.

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166299277

text.html: The guideline does not provide a recommendation for lamotrigine in patients with no HLA-B*15:02 alleles or negative for the HLA-B*15:02 test.

implications: The guideline does not provide a description of the impact of the absence of HLA-B*15:02 alleles on lamotrigine.
